So, I'm working on translating a chatbot trained on English to Spanish. I have tested it with several translations modules but none of them met my needs. The problem is mainly related of how genders are handled with the first person, the gender of the first person is undefined in English while in spanish there are specific marks to point if the speaker is male or female; for instance "I'm a teacher" could mean "Onions profesor" y "Onions profesora" in Spanish. This causes problem because usually the bot is a girl and it gets turned into masculine during the translation. What I want is a way to tell the translator that everytime it encounters the first person it assumes a given gender, for instance:
>Translate("I'm a teacher","female") = "Onions profesora"
>Translate("I'm a teacher","male") = "Onions profesor"
Is there a way to work around this problem. I hope it's clear enough, thanks in advance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
God, my OP text is very convoluted but I swear I can't find a nicer way to phrase my problem. However I noticed I can summarize it in a equivalent way:
>How do I tell google translate to translate the first person to female everytime it finds it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the problem is that english has only a handful of gendered nouns, and by convention it assumes the masculine form for a noun of ambiguous gender. so you have to state the gender if you want to specify the feminine when writing english

posts.com:
>>1314922
Smash Hit - A game where you have no player character and the camera just flies through a 3D world. You have to shoot metal balls to break glass obstacles that will hit you otherwise.

PinOut - A fairly generic pinball game but with some interesting powerups.

Trainyard Express - This is a puzzle game where you have to route colored trains to corresponding slots. You have a finite amount of space on the board, and there are really difficult challenges, sometimes with combining colors to make new ones, sometimes with using the finite amount of space to make trains "combine" so they all arrive at the exact same time. The graphics are basic, but the aesthetic is suuuuuper modern and minimalistic. Easily one of my favorite Android games ever. It's no longer on the Google play store, but you can download an old APK here if you want to try it: https://trainyard-express.en.uptodown.com/android/download

Auralux - Basically babby's first RTS. Super minimalistic game, where your "money" is also your "army". You start with a single planet, and it produces a certain number of units. When enemy units collide, they disappear. When units flow into an enemy planet, the "HP" of the planet drains until the planet becomes neutral. When when a player send enough units to flow into a neutral planet, they take over the planet and it starts producing units too. The AI in the game can be a bit stupid, but the game is always fun or challenging. There's also an Auralux 2, which is better than the first one in almost every conceivable way, but both are worth playing at least once.

Traffic Rush - A super simple game where traffic is flowing into a 4-way intersection and you can either swipe at the cars to make them speed up, or tap on them to make them stop for a moment. It can get hectic the longer the game goes on as traffic flow increases. The ads are fucking awful, so definitely only play in offline mode unless you want to fork over some money to remove the ads.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314941
continued:
Wordscapes - You're given a wheel with a certain number of letters and you basically just drag from one letter to another to form as many words as you can think of. Much better offline because the ads are annoying.

Bejeweled is always great. Plants vs Zombies (original) is always great.

First two I listed are by the same developer and have really nice 3D graphics and good music by the way. Out of all of these, Trainyard Express is probably the best, at least if you're interested in some puzzles that are satisfying to watch and difficult to solve.

So if we assume that Pulley A is rotating at 30 RPM and we are using a belt to go from Pulley A 2inch diameter to Pulley B with a 1inch diameter the ratio between these two pulleys is 1:2 which means that we will need to multiply the 1 side by 2 to make it equal to the other side of the ratio. So Pulley A rotating at 30 will be multiplied by 2 making the output on Pulley B 60 RPM from here there is a shaft directly connected to the 3-inch roller so we can assume that the roller is moving at 60 RPM. Or does this act like a reducer, I'm confused about this portion because if I take the diameter 3 and then multiply it by pi so (3*3.14) = 9.42 now we divide that by 12 inches as we are looking for FPM, not RPM comes out to (9.42/12) = 0.785 so then we take our RPM of 60 and multiply by this number so (60*0.785) = 47.1238~ So would our output be 47.1238 feet per minute of feed on this roller or am I doing something wrong, I really am having a hard time understanding if I am correct on this one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314547
It's the responsibility of the person who seeking help to make it as easy as possible to have that help provided. You made numbers up out of nothing. You didn't show working. How I am supposed to know where you went wrong? If you haven't had it drilled into you to show working that's your problem.

But now that you have shown some working.

9.42" is the circumference at C
1 revolution gives a displacement of 9.42"
60 revolutions is 60 * 9.42" = 565"
120 revolutions is 1130"
Now you see why writing 1179 was both wrong and unhelpful. It's close to an answer, not a right answer, but no one can know how you got to being close to a wrong answer.

You might have left them off while typing on computer but in written work you should be in the habit of writing proper mathematical statements including units, especially when you're using funny burgerland units that mean you just don't off by powers of 10. That way you can check cancellation of units properly.

9.42 (inch / rev) * 60 (rev / min) = 565 (inch / min)

565 (inch / min) * 1/12 (feet / inch) = 47.1 (feet / min)

You are correct with the shaft speed of 30 rpm at A. You are correct that the shaft at B rotates at double the rpm of A.

In the absence of any contrary information, we've assumed a rigid system. For a rigid body in pure translation the linear velocity is the same at all points of that body. A corresponding rule applies to a rigid body in rotation for its rotational velocity. Except at the axis where you run into problems about mathematical points which have 0 radius, all points of a rigid rotating body have the same rotational velocity ω.

If C had a 3" radius, it would have the same ω as if it had a 3" diameter because all parts must perform the same number of revolutions per unit time, but with a larger radius any point on its circumference would have a greater instantaneous linear velocity v.

>>47.1238
Too many sig fig. Check your school's rounding rules.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314662
>secure ftp connection
see there's two different things and you could be talking a out either. There's
"(secure) (FTP)", commonly called FTPS, which is FTP-but-with-SSL-encryption
and there's
"(Secure FTP)", commonly called SFTP, which is SSH's built-in file transfer over SSH additional streams.

The fact that you're trying to use SSH's port suggests you want SFTP, but you need to work out what it is you're trying to do, before you start trying to do it.

The 6 main Mega Man Battle Network games from which the Rockman.EXE anime is based upon are getting a re-release ported directly from source code this year, with actual internet-support for Net Battles (just like in the show/games story!), Chip Trading and other goodies.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314864

Harvest moon: a farming simulator, time there passes, and the calendar has 4 stations, where you can plant different crops.
Rune factory: same as harvest moon, but with a mix of combat/monster taming
Stardew valley: the western version of rune factory (and with pixelart).
The sims: after the 2, my favorite is the 3, the 4 is for free, but it looks pretty bad and glitched if you already played the 3. You can play for generations in there.
The guild: I like the 2, renaisance, same as sims, you can play for generations if your characters live enough
Mount and blade 2, bannerlord: same thing, a year has 100 days and you can play as your heir (you must have gotten a wife/husband first, and made some babies)
Rome total war: An strategy game, each turn is a month or something like that, and your emperor can die too, and must have a heir.
Civilization: An strategy game, but here there are many "ages" depending how you investigate the technology (I never finished a game, it usuallly takes hours for me to reach modern age, and by that time I got tired/bored)

Mother 3: pastoral life gets urbanised.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313872
lower video bit rate = more compression = smaller file = lower picture quality
higher video bit rate = less compression = larger file = higher picture quality

A high video bit rate must be why the video file is so large.
Different video bit rates will result in different file sizes.
And fyi, audio bit rate has little to do with file size. It's all about the video bit rate and screen size.

I am by no means an expert, but that looks like constant-current to me:
Capacitative dropper (C1, DB1, F1) provides a lowish AC voltage to a regulator chip and associated passives (U1, R1, D1, C2, L1). D1 (and maybe R1) snub the inductor, the chip and the inductor (and maybe C2) form a very rudimentary switching power supply, with the inductor smoothing everything out. The chip could be providing a constant voltage or constant current, you'd need to identify it then look at the datasheet.

>>1313784
>so if you have 6 leds each has 28V approx, more than 500% the max nominal 5V
These COB LEDs almost always have multiple LEDs in series and/or parallel internally.
If 28V is applied to them, then there's probably 6 LEDs in series, times however many strings are in parallel.
That makes it so only 4.7V is applied to each LED.
If 28V was applied to an LED with a forward voltage of 5V, it would blow up instantly.

Big Clive often covers these kinds of bulbs in his videos.
Here's one example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5HTa2jVi_rc

posts.com:
>>1314401
>they are in series and provides 5V , it wouldn't turn off (because the first one takes all the voltage).?
To elaborate, I think you're going off series* of false assumptions:
- LEDs are not resistive loads, so they don't work the same way you learned that wires, bulbs, resistors, etc. worked in school. Specifically, their "resistance" goes off a cliff when you exceed their forward voltage forward, or their breakdown voltage backwards. This drop is so steep and so sudden that it's usual to do calculations with LEDs and resistors as if the LED is a magical device that breaks the laws of physics and forces a constant voltage across itself. We subtract the forward voltages of the LEDs, then do the normal math on whatever's left
- you said the driver is a constant current driver. This doesn't actually mean it has a constant current because that's not how electricity works, but its output voltage is regulated by examining how much current it induces. So if you added more LEDs, the voltage would go up to compensate, if you removed or shorted some, the voltage would go down. It's the opposite of a traditional voltage-regulated power supply, where the input charge is constantly monitored by a computer to come up with the same output voltage, instead the charge is constantly monitored to produce the same output current. The voltage produced can vary wildly, even second-to-second.

*hoho

>>1314518
romans were superior, crusaders only had chainmail (plate armor came much later), the majority of them had basic helmets (the great helm, as basic as it looks mostly came later as well), and the quality of iron during the crusading periods wasnt significantly higher than what the romans had, the majority of it was wrought iron which is nothing compared to steel found in the later medieval period
the lance hadnt really developed into a distinct weapon either, they just carried basic spears like 90% of the rest of the army, both cavalry and footmen
they would carry a shield too, which depending on how you look at it could be effective enough to make up for a lack of armor
none of this is to say that this equipment was never effective, but the average soldier wasnt covered head to toe in chainmail, usually they had helmets, and those helmets sometimes had aventails, but even padding wasnt common
consider training too, while medieval people had a lot of wars they still didnt want to fight, and the average person might only have one time during their life where theyre called to war, for maybe a month to year period
the romans on the other hand were a lot more consistent when it came to armor and equipment, they had much better and experienced commanders due to rome being at constant war with something, they had a denser population so higher numbers, which also means replacing soldiers more easily, and they had a selection of different types of soldiers to use on the field
1 on 1 a crusader could match a roman in a fight, roman lammelar can still be countered just by chance or skill
pic rel is about what the average knight going into the middle east would look like

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'll try go with shit I watched when I was young. I would say these would be closer to 7-8 than 4 but here you go. These are all based off their english dub form.

Medabots - personally didn't watch this until I was like 10 or 11 I think but I think dub is appropriate for that age range for the most part. There's one episode where the kids go to the bad part of town, and encounter some drunks that the dub tries to censor with it's spoken dialogue implying their possessed by ghost or something. It's comical as an adult because it's pretty obvious, but as a kid it flew right over my head. There's another episode where characters backstory is being from a country in a civil war. Nothing graphic is shown, or referred to but the implications are obvious an adult, but again flew over my head. These are only 2 episodes I can really find issue with though.

Digimon Adventure - watched when I was 5, and the dub definitely got away with some stuff I'm surprised flew back then. Lots of flashes to white when a human character gets punched or hit. There's also an episode where the main character gets slapped in the face by his mom in flashback. The dub kinda tiptoes around it by not showing the slap at all and cutting forward slightly after it happened, but the character is holding his face with a red mark while his mother berates him. Still blows my mind they got away with this. Otherwise can't think of anything else that bad in the dub.
Ronin Warriors is one I watched when I was 5-6 as well. Think power rangers but Samurai. Not sure if the holds up or really adhers to modern standard though

>>1313023
The Vitello dub is probably the one you're referring to. It's pretty great honestly. Has a lot of really good voice actors that were in a lot of popular cartoons from the 90s. Glad it finally got archived after years of being lost

Different guy but expect it to not be smooth sailing, you're not going to have the easiest time of things at first but stick with it and you'll get the hang of it and it's really damn satisfying once you do.
As for what game to try, purely from a difficulty standpoint 7 (Perfect Cherry Blossom, 8 (Imperishable Night), and 13 (Ten Desires) are probably the easiest of the windows games. They've each got a different feel to them music and aesthetic wise, and different mechanics as well but the basics are all the same. Also if you wanted to play the game a certain character is from then for the most part you can do that as well, there's only maybe four games I wouldn't reccomend starting with, and that'd give you perhaps a bit more of a goal to stick with.

Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,

This question was on my kids math exam today and was wondering what answer others would get. I came to an answer of "This value is not possible to represent probability of a chance event.". The way I came up with this answer is because interpreting the likelihood that the first question will be true means that you would need to know how many questions answers are true or false on the test. Without knowing the total number of answers being true or false how can you determine the likelihood of the first question's answer is true? Below is the question straight from the exam.

The teacher gave a true and false quiz where P(true) = 0.5 for each question. Interpret the likelihood that the first question will be true.

Likely.

Unlikely.

Equally likely and unlikely.

This value is not possible to represent probability of a chance event.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314657
Equally likely and unlikely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314657
>how can you determine the likelihood of the first question's answer is true?
Because the problem statement says they're independent events:
>>1314657
>The teacher gave a true and false quiz where P(true) = 0.5 for each question.
>for each question.
However, you have hit on the philosophical problem of the coin toss, shell game, and so on: the event has already happened, so technically it's 100% likely to be whatever the result is.

However, we don't say the monty hall paradox is unsolvable just because the outcome is already decided: the person making the decision has incomplete information, so from his point of view it's a probability. People can gamble on chou-han, even though the dice have already been thrown and the probability is 100-0, because the gamblers haven't seen the dice yet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314659
If you don't mind can you explain why?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314657
>>1314661
not him, but
"P(true) = 0.5 for each question" means that any given question has a 50% chance of having a true answer (which implies that it has a 50% chance of being false). this is an explicitly stated fact in this particular situation, *but* it's not necessarily based on reality. you don't need to think about the questions beyond the first, as the guy above said they are independent, so you don't necessarily need to know how many questions there are in total

that's why i'm picking equally likely/unlikely as the best answer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314314
>How good is WINE?
It's kind of hit and miss.
A lot of tweaking is often needed to get things running well.

>Does it work the same on all distros or is better on some specific ones?
No difference in my experience.

>If a program isn't there does it mean it won't work, or just that it's a mystery how it'll work?
It could work or it might not.

>Alternatively, how useable would be a Windows VM on linux that would be used only for those couple of programs?
It's perfectly usable, it's just not as seamless as running a program normally.
You have to boot a virtual computer, and at first, install a whole OS in it.
The graphical performance isn't great, unless you use VFIO to passthrough a discrete GPU with QEMU.
Still, it's what I do instead of using Wine.

>My PC isn't very strong (8gb ram, i3-7100 CPU @ 3.90GHz 3.90 GHz)
Your CPU is fine, but you better upgrade your RAM to 16GB.
You need RAM for both the host and the VM.
8GB is already kinda low, even when you're not running VMs.

>I dunno how it could handle VMs.
Running a single VM willl be fine.

posts.com: If you're gonna run utilities, I'd just recommend finding Linux alternatives instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314321
>it's just not as seamless as running a program normally.
>You have to boot a virtual computer, and at first, install a whole OS in it.
>The graphical performance isn't great, unless you use VFIO to passthrough a discrete GPU with QEMU.
If you use Linux on a Windows host with WSL:
- it's as seamless as running a program normally: command-line programs can call each other across the windows/linux boundary, and linux GUI programs are managed by Windows's window manager
- the windows store installs the OS for you
- the graphics performance is great because windows supports GPU virtualisation (and Microsoft bullied Nvidia into not disabling it on non-quadros), so the two OSes will share the GPU

posts.com: I've never heard of whatever this is before but the music from this 'hack' franchise is amazing. Where do I start? With the original anime, or the PlayStation 2 games? Should I go back and forth? There seem to be four games in total for the original 'arc' and then three more after that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In my experience, you don't HAVE to watch the anime to play the games, and vice versa, you'll just lose out on some context.
The games aren't horrible or anything, but they play about how you expect a (single-player) simulation of an MMORPG would.
The anime's tone changes from series to series, this may or may not bother you if you prefer one tone over the other.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314343
>Where do I start?
You can start from either one of the circled titles in pic related, but I warn you: the only part of the .hack franchise that really deserves to be played is the G.U. videogame trilogy (though even that might be dated by today's standards).
Almost everything else is either terribly boring or repetitive and a general waste of time. A lot of people will tell you that SIGN is a masterpiece, and though it admittedly has some really gorgeous visuals and music, there's nothing else aside from that.
The only reason to start with previous titles is that you'll be able to witness the huge jump in quality when you get to G.U., and also catch some nice references that you would miss otherwise... but be prepared for a huge slog.

P.S.: the G.U. games have been recently remastered, but I heard the combat has been casualized, so I'd advice against that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You need to be calm and not panic, tell your parents about it
It's a mistake to think that rabies is the only disease wild animals can transmit
There's a lot of diseases that animals can carry which can be just as terrible as rabies and you don't want to wait around to wait for the symptoms
You should definitely clean the wound properly, if you don't know how to do it ask your parents
You should then try to see a doctor asap and I seriously mean ASAP
Scratching might be ok but you got bit, that's not something you should take lightly, it can transmit viruses and bacteria through the saliva
Depending on where you live rabies could be a very serious risk or no risk at all but you should still see a doctor

>>1314383
1) crop any future screen shots. They're too big to fit full size in a browser window.

2) Second pic shows only one physical device has been found in disk manager. That it appears in device manager suggests driver issues.

>>1314391
>mobo pcie 3x4 slot
>ssd pcie 4x4

3x4 means generation 3, 4 lanes
4x4 means gen 4, 4 lanes
A gen 4 device will work in the gen 3 slot but it will be about half as slow as it would in a gen 4 slot. Gen 5 drives will work in gen 3 slots too, and vice versa.

The first thing, since it's appearing in device manager, is to right click and update driver. You can also try uninstalling it in device manager, detecting new hardware and see if it turns up and installs.

Then exit and reopen disk manager to see it it turns up there, in which case you might need to initialise it.

If that doesn't work I would suggest you turn off the computer, this means at the wall. Make sure you are grounded. If you're in one of those countries that doesn't include ground connections on the plugs you'll need to figure out how to ground yourself. Check that the new drive is seated properly, possibly by removing it and reseating it. (this probably won't make much difference as it's already been found) They don't take a lot of force. They should be screwed in. It should go in the 3x4 slot, not the 3x2 slot which will be slower.

Boot into bios. I don't know your bios so I can't tell you where to find all these options.

You can try turning off CSM and Secure Boot.

Check that the M.2 drive is enabled. It may be with the SATA configuration options and the M.2 options may be like SATA IDE.

Your board has six SATA slots which will probably be SATA 0 - SATA 5. One of them will have your WD details, the other 5 are empty. There will be two more slots somewhere for the M.2 slots. Once of them should be enabled and have the details for your M.2 drive.

If that appears then it should appear in Windows and I don't know what to try if it doesn't.

Good luck.
